resource.feedbackRight: That will give me a lot to think about.
resource.question: Choose one of the ethics you just saw and explain why it is important to you.

prompts: What a strange robot that was! I wonder what it was doing? My head is full of fluff, but perhaps you could figure it out. But if it’s not a bother, could you answer something for me first?
I’m still waiting for your answer!

A wise bear once said “You can’t stay in your corner of the forest waiting for others to come to you. You have to go to them sometimes.” Which I think means you should go talk to my friends in order to help restore color to our world.

resource.feedbackRight: Exactly! Maybe you could also think about which approach appeals to you the most.
resource.question: What is your field of study at college?

prompts: Hoo hoot! Owls are known to be wise. Some even say they are sages who watch over adventurers. Which is why I chose to resemble one, hoot! I have something that could help you!
A famous owl once said “you will encounter many hardships ahead... that is all of our fates. Don’t feel discouraged, even during the toughest times!” So, would you like to try again?
I knew you would prevail! You just needed a little wisdom. You should find the others in order to seek out the other pieces of the puzzle.

resource.feedbackWrong: You might want to think about that a little more and try again.
resource.question: Is there potential for any aspect of your community work to connect to your academic coursework? Is there a political issue you are unsure about and would like to learn more? Share your thoughts here.

prompts: HI HI HI! I got a thing for you! You might want to see it! But first a question! Take your time! Think it through! Don’t rush! Answer well! Use your brain!
I’m still waiting for your answer!
YAY! Woohoo! Color! I have nothing left for you! Go go go! Find the others! I can also show you the other answers!

resource.feedbackRight: That will give me a lot to think about.
resource.question: Set one goal and one objective for yourself related to civic engagement.

prompts: I found a shiny object while digging in my garden. Maybe it can help you? But I like it, so I’ll only give it up if you really need it. So first a challenge!
I’m still waiting for your answer!
After seeing your hard work, I see that its better to help others rather than hoard things. I don’t have any more shinies.

resource.question: What is your previous experience with civic engagement? List each organization you've worked with in the past, and (briefly) what you did there.

prompts: Ah! Bonjour, my friend! Welcome to my French corner of ze forest! You’re on a some sort of quest, no? Perhaps you find the color, oui? Help me and I will help you!
Oh no! Maybe you need another attempt. Try again, oui?
Q: How many seeds does it take to fully recolor our world? A: We’ll never know unless you dare to find out!

smalltalk: My Great Grandma Turnip used to always say “Unless you try to do something beyond what you have already mastered, you will never grow.” I’m not sure if she meant that literally or figuratively. It also sounds like something Emerson once said, but what do I know? I’m just a turnip.
Did you know you can chat with other players?

resource.feedbackRight: That will give me a lot to think about.
resource.question: Which did someone say that resonated most with you? Why?

prompts: Rogga has a thing that may help you grab and carry pretty colors back to world. It’s sad with no color. Everything is so gray. Maybe help with my survey and I give you the thing?
I’m still waiting for your answer!
Rogga thinks you will be the best and bring back all the colors. Use all of the things! Want to see all of the things others say?

resource.question: Describe a time you had difficulty communicating or collaborating with others because of a difference between your respective social identities.

prompts: O-o-oh... h-h-hi. I’m h-holding something important for you.
This is tough, but important to think about!
I wish I was b-b-brave like you!

resource.feedbackRight: I can think of 42 reasons why that’s a great answer.
resource.question: Choose and answer one of these 12 questions. How does it effect your goals and objectives?

prompts: Oh! Hello! You startled me. I was just thinking about the answer to life, the universe, and everything. But you came to ask for help right? First, can you help me?
Hmm... It doesn’t seem like you took my question seriously. This is important! You want to give me another answer?

Maybe the real answer to life, the universe, and everything can be found by working with people rather than with a super computer? If so, you should try talking to the others! Maybe you can help them and find the answer?

smalltalk: Is there potential for any aspect of your community work to connect to your academic coursework? Is there a political issue you are unsure about and would like to learn more?
How many seeds do you have? Where are you going to plant them? The world is your canvas!
future

resource.answer: D) Brown hair, bilingual, New Yorker
resource.feedbackRight: Nailed it! We should totally hang out after this.
resource.feedbackWrong: Hmm... never heard that one before. Maybe you should check out the resource one more time and give it another shot.
resource.question: Which of the following would not be considered a description of someone’s “social identities”, referring issues of diversity and inclusion?
possibleAnswers: A) Latina, upper-class/privileged upbringing, Roman Catholic
B) Working class upbringing, daughter of immigrants, latina female
C) Roman Catholic, latina female, middle-class/working class upbringing
D) Brown hair, bilingual, New Yorker

prompts: CHEWY CHOMP! I hear you’re trying to spread some color. That’s great. But first, chew on this!
Not accurate. Give it another shot, why don’t ya?
GOT ANY GUM? No? Oh well. I can show you the resource again, if you want.

resource.feedbackRight: Very revealing, but of course there’s more to you than that.
resource.feedbackWrong: Are you sure you understood the question? Try again!
resource.question: List what you believe are three of the most important aspects of your social identity, that intersect to make up who you are.

prompts: This haircut is new. Tell me I look good, and I’ll give you the chance to get some really cool stuff. Oh, you flatterer, you. Here’s something that might help you...
This time, for sure. Presto!
Still not sure about this haircut. Or maybe I’m just confused about where to go. Either way, something’s gotta change! You need to get out there and take life by the horns.

smalltalk: Would you like to work in the community as a means of deciding if a certain career is right for you? Are you hoping to find your passion?
You don’t need to make your answers public, but if you do, other players can give you extra seeds.
It’s so sad the color was taken away, but I can’t shake the feeling that this has all happened before. It’s almost like something is stealing it...?
Did you learn something you didn’t already know from someone in our community? Everyone has unique knowledge to offer!
Have you seen any rainbows? I wish we still had rainbows. I remember when the rainbows went away before. I miss them.
I think you would be better off talking to someone from the forest first.

resource.feedbackRight: Bingo! Now that’s what I’m talkin’ about!
resource.feedbackWrong: That’s not right! Check the resource and give it another shot.
resource.question: True or False: There is a significant difference between the numbers of Chinatown youth and elders that are English speaking.

prompts: Did you know Chinatown is the most densely populated neighborhood of Boston? It’s history is pretty amazing. Let me share some knowledge with you.
Yo you gotta get this right before I can help you.
My bro Framp said you were alright. I’m glad we got someone who wants to work with us.

resource.question: What is your passion, and how do you want to work toward it?

prompts: YO! Framp is stoked you came to visit! You meet my bro Hamp yet? He is a little intense, but he just wants to make sure we are partners working together to strengthen our community.
See? I told you Hamp is OK! He just loves his town and wants to be a part of helping restore the color. We all want to help make our home a better place.

resource.question: Based on what students, faculty, and community members in Somerville said in the videos, name one asset of the city and one challenge.

prompts: You need help finding the color, right? I can help!
Ah. I think you need to try again.
Am I a bird with no wings or a creature with a large nose? What do you think?
smalltalk: Oh my, my — you are very skilled and talented — but you know what? I think you will find those out in the community are too. Look — I can balance a teacup on my head.
Oh my, my — you are very skilled and talented — but you know what? I think you will find those out in the community are too. Look — I can balance a teacup on my head.
Oh my, my — you are very skilled and talented — but you know what? I think you will find those out in the community are too. Look — I can balance a teacup on my head.
Remember, our community has so many assets that will be beneficial to making it an even better place for everyone. We might need some help, but we all need to be involved!
People keep confusing me with another Siri. Apparently she has a great voice and is super smart! Maybe she is related to that other unusual robot I’ve seen lurking around?
If I were you, I’d talk to the Botanist. But don’t ask him about the robot. He gets touchy for some reason.

resource.question: Tell us about either a challenge or an asset of Medford that you learned from someone in the video.

prompts: Listen. I’m taking precious time out of my scientific research to talk to you. If you need some material from me, could you help me with my research?
We need this relationship to be mutually beneficial!
Thanks for the help. I feel optimistic about the future!
smalltalk: One step, two step, three step — hit the streets and see where your feet lead you. That is what my mama always said to me when going to a new place. Walk on.
One step, two step, three step — hit the streets and see where your feet lead you. That is what my mama always said to me when going to a new place. Walk on.
One step, two step, three step — hit the streets and see where your feet lead you. That is what my mama always said to me when going to a new place. Walk on.
I wonder why the color keeps disappearing? It happens again and again!

Aunty Hums used to tell me stories about the great color thief and how it stole all of the life from our community. Then a hero helped rally the community together to get it back. A real hero is someone who inspires others. That’s what my Hums used to say and she was a wise woman!
Did you help everyone in the forest already? I know they got hit pretty hard by the grayness.

resource.feedbackWrong: Oh, I don’t think so. Maybe you should take another look?
resource.question: True or False: Tufts students use municipal services in our host communities, but Tufts is not obligated to pay taxes to the communities.

prompts: Hullo. My name is Dewdrop. I have a cold *sniff*. I found this thing. It probably has germs on it, but I’ll give it to you if you think it will help. You need to answer something for me first though.
I don’t know why you would want this germ infested thing, but I can’t give it to you until you answer my question.
Remember to always wash your hands- it’s the best way to prevent getting a cold! I don’t have hands that I can wash, so that’s probably why I’m always sick.

resource.feedbackWrong: Maybe you should review the resource and try again...
resource.question: True or False: Somerville is the most densely populated municipality in New England.

prompts: Somerville may be famous for its hipsters and farm-to-table restaurants these days, but there’s a lot more to it than that. Let’s talk about the real Somerville.
Yeah, that was a lot of information. Why don’t you take another look?
You are the best! Make good use of that shape.

resource.question: Think about your preconceptions of Chinatown as a neighborhood. How do they differ from what you saw in the resource videos?

prompts: We need our color back. This is a community-identified need. You’re helping us solve a problem that we need help with and that is important to us, but its also important to learn about our community so you understand us! Here’s a question for you.
Still waiting for that answer bub!
I’m glad you are taking the time to learn about our world! By working with us and learning about our history, your help will be so much more appreciated!
smalltalk: Hey you know what this fortune cookie says?  Seek and you shall find.  I think eating some food and talking to some folks wouldn't hurt either.
Hey you know what this fortune cookie says?  Seek and you shall find.  I think eating some food and talking to some folks wouldn't hurt either.
Hey you know what this fortune cookie says?  Seek and you shall find.  I think eating some food and talking to some folks wouldn't hurt either.
Got any seeds? You should plant them! We miss the magic of color.
Wanna see a magic trick? BEHOLD! I WILL PULL A RABBIT OUT OF MY FACE...err..that doesn’t sound right...
How will I ever put on my magic show if no one will be able to see all the pretty colors?

resource.feedbackRight: Yes. Our philosophical approach for civic engagement work with community partners is from the asset-based model. This explains why all community-based projects and opportunities should be based on community-identified needs. This does not mean that you cannot be creative and have ideas for addressing challenging issues, but unless the idea is based on a community-identified need and agreed upon with a community partner, there is little chance of success.
resource.feedbackWrong: That’s not what we think. Try again, please!
resource.question: In an assets-based philosophy, who should identify the challenges (needs) that should be addressed in the community?
resource.answer: B) Needs should be identified by assets within the community
possibleAnswers: A) Volunteers from outside should identify them, because they have a better perspective
B) Needs should be identified by assets within the community
C) Everyone should assess needs and act upon them without deliberation
D) Use a “take-it-as-it-comes” philosophy

prompts: Bloop dee doop bloop! Beep boop? Oh. Sorry. You don’t speak bloopian. What I said was: Are you here to help us? If so, I think we can help you help us!
This bloopin’ thing won’t answer itself!
If you haven’t already talked to Katamari, I bet he has some junk you could use to fix this mess!

resource.question: Is there a time that you learned something from a community member, whether a child or an elderly resident, an organization leader or member, where you were “providing service”? Please describe below.

prompts: On my way home yesterday I found this. Maybe it can help?
Maybe you could try again. I take this stuff seriously you know! I won’t just give this thing to anyone.
Hope that thing helps.

resource.question: What is one thing you learned from the website?

prompts: You humans crack me up. You all look the same! Calliope is filled with diversity. Zork and Frampton are so different, but they care about their home equally. Do you care about our community? Here is a question for you!
You have to do better than that!
Thanks for working with us. We gotta catch that darn robot! Without you it would be hard to organize all of these resources.
smalltalk: Go get ’em... but watch out for that robot. It’s been sucking up color left and right!
I saw the robot a few minutes ago. His license plate says AHR-T. I wonder what that stands for?
Are you supposed to be here? You should talk to the Botanist, or maybe head back to the Forest.
This big open field is boring without all the colors. I guess I should be thankful I still have my mailbox and house!

I love caves. I heard someone once say “It is by going down into the abyss that we recover the treasures of life. Where you stumble, there lies your treasure.” Maybe this means treasure is always found in caves? Or maybe it just means to try new things outside of your comfort zone.
Did you know you can give out seeds to other players? Click “Seed It!” if you like their public answers. Make your answers public and others can give you seeds, too.

resource.feedbackWrong: Confused? Check out the resource one more time and try again.
resource.question: Do you remember the three communities that are considered Tufts “host communities”?
possibleAnswers: A) Somerville, Chinatown, and Medford
B) Somerville, Chinatown, and Worcester
C) Somerville, Worcester, and Medford
D) Grafton, Worcester, and Medford

prompts: Hope you weren’t thinking about coming in and trying to help our community without knowing anything about us. Maybe if you prove you aren’t just here for glory and fame, and that you do want to collaborate with us to make Calliope a colorful world again, I will give you something that can help.
Try again, kid.
My initial judgments about you might have been wrong. Still, I am keeping my eye on you! Don’t try anything funny!

resource.feedbackRight: That’s right! Mayor Michael McGlynn has overseen the rebuilding of every Medford elementary and middle school since he became the Mayor in 1988.
resource.feedbackWrong: Maybe you should review the resource and try again...
resource.question: True or False: The West Medford neighborhood just recently became home to a community of African American residents.

prompts: I heard that this far off place called Medford has the Mystic River running through it. Awesome!
Aw, c’mon man! I want to know!
Thats groovy, man. I DIG. The gnarliest thing is learning about cool places! Makes you feel, you know, all like connected.

smalltalk: I always think it’s neat when new residents come to live in Calliope. We are from all over the universe, Calliope has so many different languages and cultures. Calliope is a great place to call home.
The town just isn’t the same without all the vibrant color flowing from the storefronts. Worse, we still don’t know WHY the color went away.
You don’t need to make your answers public, but if you do, other players can give you extra seeds.
Remember to talk to everyone you see. You never know who will have some useful asset that could help!
I think a real hero is someone who helps people help themselves. As much as I like videogames, I wish the heroes in them weren’t so full of themselves!
You can give seeds to other players by clicking their public responses after you answer a question. But you only have five seeds to give out each level, so use them wisely.

resource.question: What skills would you bring to a civic engagement opportunity? Check all that apply!

prompts: FACT: French Toast, while delicious, is not true toast because it’s the eggy coating that is browned, not the bread itself. Moreover it is typically prepared in a pan and therefore fried, not toasted. It should be called French Fried Egg. If you answer my question right I will give you another fact about toast. I guess I could also give you this other thing, but it isn’t as interesting.
False. Try again.
Sorry my question wasn’t about toast. I know how disappointing that must have been.

resource.question: What is one thing you learned from the website?

prompts: I heard that in this place called..Somerville?...its always summer! Is that true? No? What a misleading name.
That doesn’t make much sense.
In Calliope, there is no real weather, we just tell time by asking someone what time it is. That way, whatever time you want it to be is what time it is. Its complicated.
smalltalk: Those Paintbrush Seeds are great for getting those hard to reach places!
Those Paintbrush Seeds are great for getting those hard to reach places! How many have you found?
Not that I’m not happy to see you, but shouldn’t you be in the Forest?

resource.feedbackRight: You got your helping hat on. I dig it.
resource.question: Is there a comment from a student’s journal that you relate to or that you disagree with? Explain.

prompts: Welcome to our Ranch! It’s pretty cool, right? Like, a cool ranch? That reminds me of my favorite snack... wait, what were we doing again? Oh yeah! Busting that color swiping robot! You might need this thing.
Get your head out of the dirt and get on this!
Glad I could help. Make sure you talk to everyone else around the ranch. If you find a snack, hit me up.
smalltalk: Reflect, reflect, reflect — that’s my mantra. Try it out some time. It is very enlightening. Ohm...
Reflect, reflect, reflect — that’s my mantra. Try it out some time. It is very enlightening. Ohm...
Reflect, reflect, reflect — that’s my mantra. Try it out some time. It is very enlightening. Ohm...

resource.feedbackRight: I believe I can fly. I believe if you try you can fill the sky with color.
resource.question: Out of all the advice given in the video, what did you find most helpful, and why?

prompts: Howdy, youngin’. My name is ChickenBob, the chickenest bob in all of Calliope. I got this here thangy that might help stop that darn robot from doin’ all that color swipin’. Help me with somethin’ and I’ll give it to ya.
Who do you think I am, youngin’? You gotta put two turnips into the farm before you harvest the crops, ya know? Try again.
Hey, allright! You take care now, ya hear? You see that machine, you call up ChickenBob and he’ll bust it up allright!

smalltalk: Did you know there are wacky secrets hidden around town? You need to talk to us to find them!
One day I washed up on the shore and ChickenBob gave me a home on the ranch. There are some great folks living in this place! It’s good to get to know them. I think that’s good advice for all places!
A wise Lorax once said: “Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It’s not.”

resource.feedbackRight: By George, I think you’ve got it!
resource.feedbackWrong: Perhaps you should re-read the resource and try again!
resource.question: Which of the following are important aspects of making sure your efforts benefit both yourself and the community?
possibleAnswers: A) Maintaining a balance between your own learning and the service that you’re providing
B) Respecting community members as co-educators and partners
C) Learning about the community’s assets as well as its needs
D) Truly addressing a need that the community itself identifies
E) All of these
F) A and B

prompts: Hey! Hey! You! That robot stole all the color! Whats the point of this awesome flag if the color is empty? Argh! Robots! Is this hinge going to help you?
ah you gotta show me that this thing will help so I can use my flag!
Did you know that flags are so fun? You can wave them, you can show your support for something, and you can make your own! So fun!

resource.feedbackRight: Thanks for that! Keep fighting the good fight.
resource.question: Do you know of a goal or objective that you and the organization both share? If so, what?

prompts: My friend! Do come yonder and fill my space with all of your colors. Color, my friend, is one of the most precious gifts bestowed upon our community. A challenge for you then! The reward will prove your worth as a true adventurer!
You still must prove to me your worth, friend!
I used to be an adventurer like you, until my world got sapped of all its color. Go forth and restore!

smalltalk: I think I saw the robot headed over to the port! Did you see him there??
It’s great that you came to Calliope to help us. It’s a great responsibility. You know, like Spiderman! Great power is responsibility and it’s important. Something like that.
It would be better for you to visit the Forest or maybe the Town first.

resource.feedbackRight: That sounds like a great start. Now keep your commitment to us and bring back all the color!
resource.question: In just a few words, describe yourself (in a civic engagement context). Example: “Skilled artist, big heart”.

prompts: My name always gets me in trouble. People kept blaming me for the lack of color! Like, just because my name means “rascal” doesn’t mean I’m a bad guy! You don’t think I’m a bad guy do you? Here! I got something that will help you! That will show ’em!
Well... I think you could do better. I just don’t want to give up this piece if it isn’t going to someone who will help us.
See! I told you I was a good guy! That should go to show that judging someone based on a first impression isn’t a good idea!

resource.feedbackWrong: This is important! Please go back and take another look.
resource.question: Do you understand the safety policy of Tufts? If you will be working with people under the age of 17, have you taken the proper precautions and measures?

prompts: Oh, don’t you just love Calliope? I swear to you its much more beautiful with the colors. That nasty robot! Maybe I can help you put a stop to this gray madness? Then again, I wouldn’t want to put you in any danger. Can I trust that you know how to be safe?
I’m still waiting for that answer!
You don’t need to make your answers public, but if you do, other players can give you extra seeds.

resource.feedbackRight: That’s true. The poverty threshold for a single individual under the age of 65 is $11,334. Seems low, huh?
resource.question: True or False: A single individual earning $15,000 per year is not officially counted living below the poverty line.

prompts: Before I came to Calliope, I used to live in this place with other mushrooms. It was cool, until this huge spiky turtle dragon thing started wrecking everything! That’s when I found this place. I loved it here, that is until a robot stole all the color. Can’t a mushroom get a break? I’m sick of moving, so I’ll help you stop this thing if you do something for me first.
Be a star. Answer the question!
Sorry, but your other resources are probably in another castle... er... area.

resource.question: Think of a time when you were expected to behave professionally. What did you feel was expected of you? How did you act to ensure a strong professional relationship?

prompts: Lucky for you, I can speak over six million languages. If you want to communicate in Gleeboz or Krillin, just let me know and I can switch. In the mean time, maybe you can help show me how to be a professional. I will give you something neat if you do!
I’m not so sure, but that seems a bit strange.
According to my calculations, the color has vanished many times before! I also learned that there is something called a mega seed. Sounds fascinating!

smalltalk: Don’t forget the true defintion of humility: the state or quality of being humble. Its important!
Welcome to the Ranch! If you see the robot, shoo him away. We found him sucking up some color yesterday!
I just saw that robot fly into the Forest! Or maybe he went into the town?

resource.question: Which of the bulleted recommendations, if any, will you commit to?

prompts: Vogon knows you have the strength to find this robot and get our color back. Vogon sees all the things. Vogon knows all things. Vogon wants to help you. But first, Vogon wants you to prove yourself. Ready?
Vogon is disappointed in you.
Why don’t you talk to Oriole or PenPen? Vogon is done with you.

smalltalk: I see you’ve come! The time is here to reflect on what you’ve done.
You still have a long way to go. Come back later and I will teach the ways of social SCIENCE!

resource.feedbackWrong: Not quite. Remember, “an ounce of prevention” and all that.
resource.question: When should you begin to think about the sustainability of your work?
possibleAnswers: A) When your work commitment is over
B) During the last few weeks of your commitment
C) During the first few weeks of your commitment
D) Before you even begin

prompts: Do you ever wonder what the world will be like when you’re gone? I think the best we can hope for is to leave the world a better place! Hopefully this bit will help you. Ready?
Focus! Try again!
Was that resource helpful? I’m worried about my legacy!

smalltalk: Everyone always asks why I wear my coat in warm weather. I have to tell them it’s my fur and I can’t take it off! No one understands me...
You can view the puzzle you’re trying to solve at any time by clicking the toolbox to launch your inventory... but you knew that.

resource.feedbackRight: Great! Now go find my friend Goober to talk more about how you’ll reflect on things.
resource.question: In your own words, what is reflection, and why is it important?

prompts: I love the water! When you bring all the color back, my water view will be incredible! I want to help. Here’s a question.
Water... pools... reflection pools... reflection... it all makes sense now!

smalltalk: I wonder who could have built that robot? You know, the Botanist builds things sometimes. He made those special seeds!
I wonder who could have built that robot?

resource.question: Which one of these tips do you think most applies to you?

prompts: What was that? Speak up! If I hear a right answer from you, I’ll give you something that will help!
I hear you’ve been reflecting on things. That’s awesome!

resource.feedbackRight: That’s something I can get behind.
resource.question: How might you develop your leadership capacity?

prompts: Are you here to take my order? Finally! I’ll have three large black coffees. Oh, it’s you! I have something for you that might help...
I’ll give you a hint if you give me some COFFEE! Eh, just try again.
I know you’re doing a good job, because most of the color has come back!

resource.feedbackRight: Awesome! I want to take a class on towels, and their relevance to galactic travel.
resource.question: Complete this thought: I am now interested in taking a course on...

prompts: Hm. You’re the one who’s bringing back all the color? I thought it might be you.. I can help you.
I’ll give you the same advice I give everyone: Get educated, and watch out for robots!

smalltalk: I saw the robot a little while ago. It had this funny look... like it’s planning something BIG.
Do you make your answers public? You know you can get way more seeds that way!
The Botanist is great and everything, but he’s been acting kind of nervous ever since that robot showed up!
You’re new here! We’ll help you out later, but first you need to solve more of the enigma!

resource.feedbackRight: That sounds great. I know you can do it!
resource.question: Name one connection that you would like to further explore.

prompts: Have you ever thought about where the future might take you? Wherever you go, this resource might help!
You’re like some color prodigy! I feel smarter and more artistic just by knowing you.

resource.question: Select one of the actions on the previous page that you will commit to, and explain your choice.

prompts: I thought these things were raisins, but they’re really seeds! Want some? Then answer my question.
It’s peanut butter and jelly time!

resource.question: Do you see a connection between your work in the community and thoughts about your future career? If so, how?

prompts: I may be little, but I’m packing some mighty big thoughts. Let’s see if we’re on the same wavelength. If we are, I’ll give you something that just might help you out!
Remember, size matters not! Only knowledge. Reflect on that.

resource.feedbackWrong: Did we read the same resource? Try again.
resource.question: True or False: According to Dr. Astin’s study, participating in community service can have a positive impact on your academic performance.

prompts: I’ve still got plenty of seeds left. I’m supposed to give them to whoever can answer this. Is that you?
I can still give you a seed or two if you try again!
I’m raising my hand because I have a question... and you already answered it.

resource.question: Who benefits from evaluating the impact of your work?
possibleAnswers: A) You
B) The organization(s) running the program
C) The host community where the program was run
D) All of these
E) B and C

prompts: I know someone who looks like me, except their coat is really just fur. Can you believe that? Here’s something else interesting: a question for you to answer.
I’ll give you another shot, but only because I like you.
I think we all learned something important, today. When you figure out what it is, tell me! Or better yet, tell the Botanist!

smalltalk: I’ve been thinking a lot about the future lately. What will happen if the color just goes away again? What will we do then?
Thanks for bringing the color back, but I worry about the future.

resource.question: What is the answer?

prompts: Answer my question?
Try again.
Welcome back.
smalltalk: Hi! I work for the Botanist. I feel so lucky to be close to such genius. The Botanist wanted me to tell you that you can view the current recipe and all the research pieces you have collected by clicking your inventory (in the bottom left corner).

Hi! I work for the Botanist. I feel so lucky to be close to such genius. The Botanist wanted me to tell you that you can view the current recipe and all the research pieces you have collected by clicking your inventory (in the bottom left corner).
There is no future. I destroyed the buggers.

resource.question: You’ve learned a lot about the host community you chose. Now it’s time to think about all the assets, challenges, and tips the stakeholders discussed. Select one of them that stuck with you and share it here, along with why you think it is important. If necessary, you can go back and review the resource.
resource.feedbackRight: Excellent. Here's the piece you were looking for. Remember: use it only for good.

prompts: [First time message is hijacked by custom code. Do not edit.]
Ah, welcome back. I see you’ve got the knowledge needed to answer my question. Are you ready?
Always nice to see a familiar face! Hope you found that piece useful. Take care, and watch out for robots.
